problem.tex: Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a locally bounded family of holomorphic functions on a region $\Omega$. Prove (without invoking Montel's theorem) that $\mathcal{F}$ is equicontinuous at every point of $\Omega$.

solution.tex: Suppose that $\mathcal{F}$ is locally bounded at all points in $\Omega$. Take the constants $M,r$ from the definition of locally bounded, also choose $r$ small enough so that $\overline{B_r(z_0)}\subset\Omega$. That is, for all $z\in B_r(z_0)$ and all $f\in\mathcal{F}$, we have asusmed that $|f(z)|\leq M$. Let $\epsilon>0$ be given. Let $z\in\Omega$ with $|z-z_0|<\frac{r}{2}$. Let $\gamma$ be the circle $|z-z_0|=r$. By Cauchy's integral formula applied to arbitrary $f\in\mathcal{F}$, \[|f(z)-f(z_0)|=\left|\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw-\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{f(w)}{w-z_0}dw\right|=\frac{1}{2\pi}\left|\int_\gamma\frac{f(w)(z-z_0)}{(w-z)(w-z_0)}dw\right|\] \[\leq\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\left|\frac{f(w)(z-z_0)}{(w-z)(w-z_0)}\right||dw|.\] Here we will use some bounds. $|f(w)|\leq M$, $|w-z_0|=r$, and $|w-z|\geq\frac{r}{2}$. Thus \[\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\left|f(w)(z-z_0)\frac{1}{w-z}\frac{1}{w-z_0}\right||dw|\leq\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma M|z-z_0|\frac{2}{r}\frac{1}{r}|dw|=\frac{M}{\pi r^2}|z-z_0|\int_\gamma|dw|=\frac{2M}{r}|z-z_0|.\] Therefore if we choose $\delta$ to be $0<\delta<\frac{r}{2}$ (so this whole argument applies) and less than $\frac{r\epsilon}{2M}$, then we have shown that $\mathcal{F}$ is equicontinuous because \[|f(z)-f(z_0)|\leq\frac{2M}{r}\delta<\frac{2M}{r}\frac{r\epsilon}{2M}=\epsilon.\]
